info.title: CarbonMapper Data Platform API
info.description:
Welcome to the Carbon Mapper data API, a programmatic resource for accessing and analyzing methane (CH4) and carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions data. Our API provides access to a wide set of geospatially-oriented emissions data, including plume and source data, atmospheric retrievals, and RGB images, empowering users to conduct insightful research and develop innovative applications.

Caution: API results may contain uncalibrated Tanager first light data

#### Usage Restrictions:
To ensure the the API remains responsive to a wide range of users, we implement restrictions designed to prevent excessive resource use, such as rate limiting. When using data from the Carbon Mapper data API, you agree to our [Terms of Use](https://carbonmapper.org/terms) and to cite Carbon Mapper as the data provider.

Please visit our public platform page to view [API tutorials](https://github.com/carbon-mapper/platform-public/tree/main/tutorials) or report issues in our [tracker](https://github.com/carbon-mapper/platform-public/issues).

x-codeSamples.source:
import requests

access_token = "<your_access_token>"
response = requests.get(
    "https://api.carbonmapper.org/api/v1/account/search-requests",
    headers={"Authorization": f"Bearer {access_token}"},
)

import requests

access_token = "<your_access_token>"
response = requests.get(
    "https://api.carbonmapper.org/api/v1/account/me",
    headers={"Authorization": f"Bearer {access_token}"},
)

import requests

access_token = "<your_access_token>"
response = requests.get(
    "https://api.carbonmapper.org/api/v1/account/users",
    headers={"Authorization": f"Bearer {access_token}"},
)

post.description: Newly registered users will receive an email with instructions for account verification.

x-codeSamples.source:
import requests

json_data = {
    "email": "user@domain.com",
    "password1": "3v@b8cG4",
    "password2": "3v@b8cG4",
    "first_name": "John",
    "last_name": "Doe",
}
response = requests.post(
    "https://api.carbonmapper.org/api/v1/account/register",
    json=json_data,
)

import requests

access_token = "<your_access_token>"
response = requests.get(
    "https://api.carbonmapper.org/api/v1/account/tokens",
    headers={"Authorization": f"Bearer {access_token}"},
)

get.summary: Get plume by Primary Key (UUID) or colloquial id (<scene_id>-<letter>)

x-codeSamples.source:
import requests

json_data = {
    "geometry_json": {'coordinates': [-119.08930932022109, 35.49648630200113], 'type': 'Point'},
    "scene_id": "47ac573b-504e-44c4-a998-0f3c19fa0f21",
    "gas": "CH4",
}
access_token = "<your_access_token>"
response = requests.post(
    "https://api.carbonmapper.org/api/v1/catalog/plume",
    json=json_data,
    headers={"Authorization": f"Bearer {access_token}"},
)

parameters.name: plume_ids

schema.description: Universally unique object identifier randomly generated using UUIDv4
schema.title: Plume IDs

parameters.description: Universally unique object identifier randomly generated using UUIDv4

parameters.name: plume_names

schema.description: A unique identifier for each plume in the format `{platform}{YYYYMMDD}t{HHMMSS}p{part}`. The first three characters represent the platform (e.g., GAO for Global Airborne Observatory), followed by the acquisition date and time in ISO 8601 UTC format. The part suffix (e.g., 'p0000-A') retains key information from the original radiance filename and indicates the order of multiple plumes detected in the same image.

parameters.name: has_phme

schema.description:
Filter for results that contain a Potentially Harmful Methane Event. PHME is an experimental product defined as a methane emissions event whose resulting surface-level concentrations exceed at least one safety or health-based concentration threshold:
* Proximity-only: plume origin is within 100m of the nearest identifiable sensitive receptor (any potentially human-occupied building) which addresses smallest detectable plumes close to people, OR
* Size and proximity: observed plume length exceeds 1000 meters AND overlaps nearest identifiable sensitive receptor – which indicates a reasonably high emission event and potential for surface mixing ratios exceeding a certain lower explosive limit (LEL) within proximity to people
schema.title: Has PHME

parameters.description:

* Proximity-only: plume origin is within 100m of the nearest identifiable sensitive receptor (any potentially human-occupied building) which addresses smallest detectable plumes close to people, OR
* Size and proximity: observed plume length exceeds 1000 meters AND overlaps nearest identifiable sensitive receptor – which indicates a reasonably high emission event and potential for surface mixing ratios exceeding a certain lower explosive limit (LEL) within proximity to people

parameters.name: published_at_datetime

schema.description:
The date/time or date/time range by which to filter results. The start and end date/times should be separated by a forward slash. Date/times must be formatted according to [RFC 3339](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). Refer to the [STAC specification](https://github.com/radiantearth/stac-spec/blob/master/item-spec/item-spec.md#properties-object) for additional information.

Date/times can be represented as dates, date/times, closed intervals, and open intervals.

parameters.name: source_name

schema.description: A source name describes an ephemeral geospatial point around which plumes of the same gas and sector are historically clustered. Clusters are defined using the [ST_ClusterDBSCAN](https://postgis.net/docs/ST_ClusterDBSCAN.html) function. A source can be defined by a minimum of one _core_ plume, and _border_ plumes can only be matched within a 2km box bounding the core plume. Source names are formatted as `<gas>_<sector>_<eps>_<longitude>_<latitude>`. See `ST_ClusterDBSCAN` documentation for information about how `eps` (epsilon, the maximal distance from the core plume for another plume to qualify as a bordering geometry) is used.
schema.title: Source Name

parameters.description: A source name describes an ephemeral geospatial point around which plumes of the same gas and sector are historically clustered. A source can be defined by a minimum of one _core_ plume, and _border_ plumes can only be matched within a 2km box bounding the core plume. Source names are formatted as `<gas>_<sector>_<eps>_<longitude>_<latitude>`. See `ST_ClusterDBSCAN` documentation for information about how `eps` (epsilon, the maximal distance from the core plume for another plume to qualify as a bordering geometry) is used.

get.description:
When downloading data, a hard limit is imposed, use offset for pagination:
 - **limit**: default is 500, max is 1000
 - **offset**: default is 0, no max
 - **datetime**: datetime interval, ex: "2018-02-12T00:00:00Z/2018-03-18T12:31:12Z"

For other parameters, refer to **PlumeFilterSchema** in _Schemas_ section below.

Date/times can be represented as dates, date/times, closed intervals, and open intervals.

parameters.name: source_name

schema.description: A source name describes an ephemeral geospatial point around which plumes of the same gas and sector are historically clustered. Clusters are defined using the [ST_ClusterDBSCAN](https://postgis.net/docs/ST_ClusterDBSCAN.html) function. A source can be defined by a minimum of one _core_ plume, and _border_ plumes can only be matched within a 2km box bounding the core plume. Source names are formatted as `<gas>_<sector>_<eps>_<longitude>_<latitude>`. See `ST_ClusterDBSCAN` documentation for information about how `eps` (epsilon, the maximal distance from the core plume for another plume to qualify as a bordering geometry) is used.

A source can be defined by a minimum of one _core_ plume, and _border_ plumes can only be matched within a 2km box bounding the core plume. Source names are formatted as `<gas>_<sector>_<eps>_<longitude>_<latitude>`. demonstrating the use of this resource can be found in the
[platform-public](https://github.com/carbon-mapper/platform-public/) repository.

Responses are paginated. Refer to limit and offset query parameter specifications documented below. Refer to the
tutorial for an example of compiling a single CSV from multiple paginated requests.

* Proximity-only: plume origin is within 100m of the nearest identifiable sensitive receptor (any potentially human-occupied building) which addresses smallest detectable plumes close to people, OR
* Size and proximity: observed plume length exceeds 1000 meters AND overlaps nearest identifiable sensitive receptor – which indicates a reasonably high emission event and potential for surface mixing ratios exceeding a certain lower explosive limit (LEL) within proximity to people

get.description:
This endpoint will return scenes that have been published and are eligible
to use for null detection.

The requirements for this is for the cloud cover
percentage to be <= 25%, and for the scene to have been assessed.

Specify parameter not_cloudy=True or cloud_cover_pct_max=30 for your own threshold.

schema.description:
Filter for results that contain a Potentially Harmful Methane Event. PHME is an experimental product defined as a methane emissions event whose resulting surface-level concentrations exceed at least one safety or health-based concentration threshold:
* Proximity-only: plume origin is within 100m of the nearest identifiable sensitive receptor (any potentially human-occupied building) which addresses smallest detectable plumes close to people, OR
* Size and proximity: observed plume length exceeds 1000 meters AND overlaps nearest identifiable sensitive receptor – which indicates a reasonably high emission event and potential for surface mixing ratios exceeding a certain lower explosive limit (LEL) within proximity to people

Filter for results that contain a Potentially Harmful Methane Event. PHME is an experimental product defined as a methane emissions event whose resulting surface-level concentrations exceed at least one safety or health-based concentration threshold:
* Proximity-only: plume origin is within 100m of the nearest identifiable sensitive receptor (any potentially human-occupied building) which addresses smallest detectable plumes close to people, OR
* Size and proximity: observed plume length exceeds 1000 meters AND overlaps nearest identifiable sensitive receptor – which indicates a reasonably high emission event and potential for surface mixing ratios exceeding a certain lower explosive limit (LEL) within proximity to people

parameters.name: source_name

schema.description: A source name describes an ephemeral geospatial point around which plumes of the same gas and sector are historically clustered. Clusters are defined using the [ST_ClusterDBSCAN](https://postgis.net/docs/ST_ClusterDBSCAN.html) function. A source can be defined by a minimum of one _core_ plume, and _border_ plumes can only be matched within a 2km box bounding the core plume. Source names are formatted as `<gas>_<sector>_<eps>_<longitude>_<latitude>`. See `ST_ClusterDBSCAN` documentation for information about how `eps` (epsilon, the maximal distance from the core plume for another plume to qualify as a bordering geometry) is used.
schema.title: Source Name

parameters.description: A source name describes an ephemeral geospatial point around which plumes of the same gas and sector are historically clustered. Clusters are defined using the [ST_ClusterDBSCAN](https://postgis.net/docs/ST_ClusterDBSCAN.html) function. A source can be defined by a minimum of one _core_ plume, and _border_ plumes can only be matched within a 2km box bounding the core plume. Source names are formatted as `<gas>_<sector>_<eps>_<longitude>_<latitude>`. See `ST_ClusterDBSCAN` documentation for information about how `eps` (epsilon, the maximal distance from the core plume for another plume to qualify as a bordering geometry) is used.

get.description:
This endpoint generates spatial clusters over plumes filtered via same
parameters as those used for the plume-csv and plumes/related endpoints.

Core space/time parameters:
 - **datetime**: datetime interval, ex: "2018-02-12T00:00:00Z/2018-03-18T12:31:12Z"
 - **bbox**: The bounding box is a 4-tuple (xmin, ymin, xmax, ymax) representing the coordinates.        It's formatted with individual parameters for the longitude and latitude of the lower left corner         followed by the upper right corner. For example: **bbox=-109.04&bbox=31.33&bbox=-103.01&bbox=37.01**

Additional key parameters used for DBSCAN algorithm are:
 - **eps**: [epsilon] minimal distance between points in meters
 - **minpoints**: minimal number of points required to make a cluster

source: https://postgis.net/docs/ST_ClusterDBSCAN.html

For other plume filter parameters to **PlumeFilterSchema** in _Schemas_ section below.

parameters.name: source_name

schema.description: A source name describes an ephemeral geospatial point around which plumes of the same gas and sector are historically clustered. Clusters are defined using the [ST_ClusterDBSCAN](https://postgis.net/docs/ST_ClusterDBSCAN.html) function. A source can be defined by a minimum of one _core_ plume, and _border_ plumes can only be matched within a 2km box bounding the core plume. Source names are formatted as `<gas>_<sector>_<eps>_<longitude>_<latitude>`. See `ST_ClusterDBSCAN` documentation for information about how `eps` (epsilon, the maximal distance from the core plume for another plume to qualify as a bordering geometry) is used.

parameters.name: source_name

schema.description: A source name describes an ephemeral geospatial point around which plumes of the same gas and sector are historically clustered. Clusters are defined using the [ST_ClusterDBSCAN](https://postgis.net/docs/ST_ClusterDBSCAN.html) function. A source can be defined by a minimum of one _core_ plume, and _border_ plumes can only be matched within a 2km box bounding the core plume. Source names are formatted as `<gas>_<sector>_<eps>_<longitude>_<latitude>`. See `ST_ClusterDBSCAN` documentation for information about how `eps` (epsilon, the maximal distance from the core plume for another plume to qualify as a bordering geometry) is used.

parameters.name: has_phme

schema.description:
Filter for results that contain a Potentially Harmful Methane Event. PHME is an experimental product defined as a methane emissions event whose resulting surface-level concentrations exceed at least one safety or health-based concentration threshold:
* Proximity-only: plume origin is within 100m of the nearest identifiable sensitive receptor (any potentially human-occupied building) which addresses smallest detectable plumes close to people, OR
* Size and proximity: observed plume length exceeds 1000 meters AND overlaps nearest identifiable sensitive receptor – which indicates a reasonably high emission event and potential for surface mixing ratios exceeding a certain lower explosive limit (LEL) within proximity to people

x-codeSamples.source:
import requests

response = requests.get(
    "https://api.carbonmapper.org/api/v1/stac/conformance",
)

get.summary: Get an administrative area geojson by model and primary key

post.summary: Create or Update Operator Report [Limited Beta]
post.description:
Create an Operator Report by sending a request payload without an id.
Update an Operator Report by sending a request payload with the operator report's id.

Any fields not provided in the request payload will be left unchanged.
To unset a field, provide an empty string for the field.
The endpoint does not currently support unsetting the leak image.
**Request must be formatted as multipart/form-data.**

Carbon Mapper does not verify or endorse operator-submitted reports and reserves the right
not to post or to remove submitted information from the Data Portal.
Reports are provided on a voluntary basis as part of a best-effort research and transparency capability,
and may not reflect validated emissions data.
Operator investigation of emission events posted on the portal and voluntary submittal of any information
does not constitute acceptance or confirmation by the operator of the estimated emission rate.
Identified emissions may also be the product of normal operations that comply with the various state and/or
federal regulations and permit limits.

id.description:
**[Required on Update]** UUID of existing report to update. Do not include for new reports.

Example: `a50766c6-4ae3-40bd-86b2-f7a5ffde1ffb`
id.title: Id

plume_identifier.description:
**[Required on Create]** Plume UUID or Plume ID

Examples: `a50766c6-4ae3-40bd-86b2-f7a5ffde1ffb`, `GAO20230628t191011p0000-B`
plume_identifier.title: Plume Identifier

investigation_date.description:
**[Required on Create]** Date of investigation. Date must be ISO-formatted according to [RFC 3339](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3339#section-5.6)

Examples: `2025-01-23`
investigation_date.title: Investigation Date

reported_by.description: Name of the person reporting the incident
reported_by.title: Reported By

allOf.description:
- UNEXPECTED: unexpected leak/malfunction
- EXPECTED: expected process emission
- UNKNOWN: geolocation error or source not located at operator’s facility, couldn’t identify potential source / unknown
allOf.title: Classification

classification.description:
Report Classification. One of the following:
* **Unexpected**: unexpected leak/malfunction people
* **Expected**: expected process emission
* **Unknown**: geolocation error or source not located at operator's facility, couldn't identify potential source / unknown

**Additional fields below allowed/prohibited based on classification**
classification.title: Classification

equipment_group.description: **[Classification UNEXPECTED & EXPECTED]** A general category of infrastructure or process equipment, such as a separator, tank, or wellhead, that contains or supports one or more potential leak points and reflects standard functional groupings used in oil and gas or industrial systems
equipment_group.title: Equipment Group

component.description: **[Classification UNEXPECTED]** A specific part or connection point within an equipment group, such as a valve, flange, or threaded fitting, that represents the likely source of a leak and corresponds to a discrete, repairable element in the system
component.title: Component

location.description:
**[Classification UNEXPECTED]** Point Coordinates (Longitude, Latitude).

To send the pair of coordinates via multipart/form-data, use the `location` key twice. First for longitude and second for latitude (curl e.g. `-F 'location=-87.6289' -F 'location=41.8977'`)
location.title: Location

confirmed_date.description:
**[Classification UNEXPECTED]** Confirmation date.Date must be ISO-formatted according to [RFC 3339](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3339#section-5.6)

Examples: `2025-01-23`
confirmed_date.title: Confirmed Date

leak_image.description: **[Classification UNEXPECTED]** Image file to be sent via multipart/form-data using the `leak_image` key (curl e.g. `-F 'leak_image=@path/to/image.jpg'`)
leak_image.title: Leak Image

repair_date.description:
**[Classification UNEXPECTED]** Repair date. Date must be ISO-formatted according to [RFC 3339](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3339#section-5.6)

Examples: `2025-01-23`
repair_date.title: Repair Date

verification_date.description:
**[Classification UNEXPECTED]** Verification date. Date must be ISO-formatted according to [RFC 3339](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3339#section-5.6)

Examples: `2025-01-23`
verification_date.title: Verification Date

activity_date.description:
**[Classification EXPECTED]** Activity date. Date must be ISO-formatted according to [RFC 3339](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3339#section-5.6)

Examples: `2025-01-23`
activity_date.title: Activity Date

has_phme.description:
Filter for results that contain a Potentially Harmful Methane Event. PHME is an experimental product defined as a methane emissions event whose resulting surface-level concentrations exceed at least one safety or health-based concentration threshold:
* Proximity-only: plume origin is within 100m of the nearest identifiable sensitive receptor (any potentially human-occupied building) which addresses smallest detectable plumes close to people, OR
* Size and proximity: observed plume length exceeds 1000 meters AND overlaps nearest identifiable sensitive receptor – which indicates a reasonably high emission event and potential for surface mixing ratios exceeding a certain lower explosive limit (LEL) within proximity to people
has_phme.title: Has PHME

source_name.description: A source name describes an ephemeral geospatial point around which plumes of the same gas and sector are historically clustered. Clusters are defined using the [ST_ClusterDBSCAN](https://postgis.net/docs/ST_ClusterDBSCAN.html) function. A source can be defined by a minimum of one _core_ plume, and _border_ plumes can only be matched within a 2km box bounding the core plume. Source names are formatted as `<gas>_<sector>_<eps>_<longitude>_<latitude>`. See `ST_ClusterDBSCAN` documentation for information about how `eps` (epsilon, the maximal distance from the core plume for another plume to qualify as a bordering geometry) is used.

Date/times can be represented as dates, date/times, closed intervals, and open intervals.

OperatorReportOut.description:
Excluding:
- user, which we only keep for internal use
- leak_image, which is a file upload
OperatorReportOut.title: OperatorReportOut

Classification.description:
- UNEXPECTED: unexpected leak/malfunction
- EXPECTED: expected process emission
- UNKNOWN: geolocation error or source not located at operator’s facility, couldn’t identify potential source / unknown
Classification.title: Classification

OperatorReportIn.description: Excluding user, leak_image, and published for which there is logic in the endpoint

id.description:
**[Required on Update]** UUID of existing report to update. Do not include for new reports.

Example: `a50766c6-4ae3-40bd-86b2-f7a5ffde1ffb`
id.title: Id

plume_identifier.description:
**[Required on Create]** Plume UUID or Plume ID

Examples: `a50766c6-4ae3-40bd-86b2-f7a5ffde1ffb`, `GAO20230628t191011p0000-B`
plume_identifier.title: Plume Identifier

investigation_date.description:
**[Required on Create]** Date of investigation. Date must be ISO-formatted according to [RFC 3339](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3339#section-5.6)

Examples: `2025-01-23`
investigation_date.title: Investigation Date

reported_by.description: Name of the person reporting the incident
reported_by.title: Reported By

allOf.description:
- UNEXPECTED: unexpected leak/malfunction
- EXPECTED: expected process emission
- UNKNOWN: geolocation error or source not located at operator’s facility, couldn’t identify potential source / unknown
allOf.title: Classification

classification.description:
Report Classification. One of the following:
* **Unexpected**: unexpected leak/malfunction people
* **Expected**: expected process emission
* **Unknown**: geolocation error or source not located at operator's facility, couldn't identify potential source / unknown

**Additional fields below allowed/prohibited based on classification**
classification.title: Classification

equipment_group.description: **[Classification UNEXPECTED & EXPECTED]** A general category of infrastructure or process equipment, such as a separator, tank, or wellhead, that contains or supports one or more potential leak points and reflects standard functional groupings used in oil and gas or industrial systems
equipment_group.title: Equipment Group

component.description: **[Classification UNEXPECTED]** A specific part or connection point within an equipment group, such as a valve, flange, or threaded fitting, that represents the likely source of a leak and corresponds to a discrete, repairable element in the system
component.title: Component

location.description:
**[Classification UNEXPECTED]** Point Coordinates (Longitude, Latitude).

To send the pair of coordinates via multipart/form-data, use the `location` key twice. First for longitude and second for latitude (curl e.g. `-F 'location=-87.6289' -F 'location=41.8977'`)
location.title: Location

confirmed_date.description:
**[Classification UNEXPECTED]** Confirmation date.Date must be ISO-formatted according to [RFC 3339](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3339#section-5.6)

Examples: `2025-01-23`
confirmed_date.title: Confirmed Date

repair_date.description:
**[Classification UNEXPECTED]** Repair date. Date must be ISO-formatted according to [RFC 3339](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3339#section-5.6)

Examples: `2025-01-23`
repair_date.title: Repair Date

verification_date.description:
**[Classification UNEXPECTED]** Verification date. Date must be ISO-formatted according to [RFC 3339](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3339#section-5.6)

Examples: `2025-01-23`
verification_date.title: Verification Date

activity_date.description:
**[Classification EXPECTED]** Activity date. Date must be ISO-formatted according to [RFC 3339](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3339#section-5.6)

Examples: `2025-01-23`
activity_date.title: Activity Date
